reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s main optimistic alternative to WAM-convergence—partial AM-convergence plus bargaining/trade as a ‘more realistic and promising’ route to mostly-great futures—so it is fairly central, though not fully (the essay also leans on other dynamics and already flags major blockers like threats and power concentration). The critique offers several substantive objections that, if right, reduce the robustness of the trade story: (i) bargaining depends on baselines/outside options/power; (ii) many moral views have sacred/lexical/deontic features that make compromise hard or incoherent; (iii) spatial/resource separability assumptions can fail when values depend on global properties. These points weaken the optimism but don’t fully refute the position because the essay already partially incorporates related caveats (e.g., power distribution, threats, decision-procedure sensitivity) and does not claim trade is reliable in all cases. Most claims are plausible and directionally correct, though somewhat overstated (even deontic/lexical views can often be represented in decision models, and ‘iron-clad contracts’ might mitigate some strategic/mistrust issues). The critique is clear, focused, and contains little filler.
title: Moral bargaining assumptions ignore non-tradeable values and global interdependencies
